definitions: The limitation on throughput caused by the need for a CPU to access data from memory over a shared bus, which can become a bottleneck when the CPU's processing speed is much faster than the memory access speed.
A performance limitation in computer architectures where the rate at which data can be transferred between the CPU and memory is significantly slower than the rate at which the CPU can process data.
examples: Addressing the Von Neumann Bottleneck is crucial for future computing.
The Von Neumann Bottleneck limits the performance of many modern computers.
New memory technologies aim to alleviate the Von Neumann Bottleneck.
